comments.text:
+extraordinaryy12 I meant that in the beginning of the movie, there wasn't 
a villain introduced. So it made it easy to predict that Hans would be the 
bad guy. Besides, why would they introduce her to Kristoff & have the 
trolls sing that stupid "Fixer-Upper" song? Are we that dumbed down as a 
society to not see the foreshadowing? I seriously worry about our school 
system when people no longer use critical thinking skills anymore.
comments.author: YourMajesty143

comments.text:
+YourMajesty143 There was a real villain - Hans. He pretended to fall in 
love with Anna so that he could take over Arendelle.
comments.author: extraordinaryy12

comments.text:
+Sharon Wang I also found it predictable. There was no real villain so you 
knew it was going to be a character already introduced. Weasel was too 
comical, Elsa was too innocent, and so that left a guy wanting to marry too 
quickly. Plus they introduced her to Kristoff. I could already see she was 
gonna end up with him way before the fixer-upper song. They rushed alot of 
the plot. We don't get a chance to even see enough character development to 
care about them. For instance, the parents were just a plot device so I 
can't sympathize with their death. We're supposed to immediately accept a 
troll adopting a little boy and A. Not get creeped out B. Not wonder where 
his family is. I'm also supposed to believe that Elsa stayed in her room 
all those years and never interacted with Anna or anyone else. I'm then 
also supposed to buy the fact that these trolls exist without any 
background as to who they are or why they're there and that the King & 
Queen know them personally. Yes, it's a fantasy movie but there should 
still be layers and context to create a thread through the plot. Instead it 
results in one jumbled mess that I'm force fed to swallow. Anna is the only 
character I liked, everything else was just filler. No real dimension or 
depth. Look at other Disney movies and you'll see the way those captured 
you vs the way this one does. This one is well-liked bc it has some good 
jokes and is stuffed to the brim with feel-good, back to back songs. But as 
an actual story, it leaves a lot to be desired imho.
comments.author: YourMajesty143

top_comment.text:
Just because it did amazing in the box office doesn't mean it deserves an 
Oscar. The Wind Rises was a more creative, romantic, thoughtful, 
imaginative, ~ I mean the list goes on ~ movie than Frozen. It had a better 
plot and though not everyone (especially kids) may be able to relate to it 
due to cultural and historical reasons, it touched peoples' hearts about 
following your dream, the right way to follow your dream, about sacrifice, 
family, and love. I find the Oscars' judgement and attention on the 
animation category ridiculous. Animation isn't just about making it 
relatable to kids. It goes way beyond that. It's about making a statement 
and though Frozen certainly make a statement, it incomparable to the 
statement The Wind Rises made.﻿
